awd_titl_txt: EAGER/Collaborative Research: Programmed Stimuli-responsive Mesoscale Polymers Inspired by Worm Blobs as Emergent Super-Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) grant will support fundamental research aimed at developing novel materials composed of stimuli-responsive filaments. The long-term desired behavior of these materials is inspired by the behavior of 1-cm-long California blackworms (Lumbriculus variegatus, Annelida: Clitellata: Lumbriculidae), a fascinating organism that collectively self-assembles to form functional worm blobs.  The three-dimensional, soft, and tangled blob behaves as a living material that responds to environmental stresses through dynamic transformations of the blob’s morphology. The specific goals of this EAGER project are two-fold: to conduct biophysical experiments and mathematical analysis on living worms, and to synthesize soft, flexible, filament-like structures in polymer solutions. The behavior of both biological and synthetic systems will be studied at the level of individual filaments, pairs of twisted filaments, and collections of interacting structures. Understanding the properties and movements of these types of filaments has direct implications for creating novel materials, flexible robots, and objects that are pre-programmed to perform useful functions in response to external stimuli such as light, heat, or chemical reagents.  The research team will include students from diverse disciplines and under-represented groups, thus adding powerful educational impact to the project and enriching its societal and human impact. 

This EAGER project will synthesize worm-inspired pre-programmed filamentous structures in polymer solutions capable of exhibiting tangling and untangling dynamics in a triggered fashion.  While physically entangled filament-like structures are of great interest at both the molecular and macroscopic size scales, the interactions of structures of intermediate size, termed mesoscale, are not well understood. This project seeks to identify the chemistry, architectures, and most useful stimuli that enable collective systems of mesoscale polymers (MSPs) to readily tangle and untangle on command. Rudimentary segmental actuation of filamentous MSPs has been demonstrated by the research team. However, achieving intricate knotting and unknotting of collective filamentous structures remains a challenge. Here, chiral, twisting, and braiding mesoscale polymer structures will be synthesized using photochemical and fluid-induced methods. These efforts will be guided by fundamental research on the mechanics of knotting and unknotting in the living system. Together, these efforts could bring on a leap in materials synthesis while uncovering new foundational capabilities in the synthetic design of complex interacting filamentous structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Summar

This collaborative project focused on the development of mesoscale polymer ribbons that can mimic Lubriculus variegatus worms, which form aggregate blobs in nature. Lubriculus variegatus worm blobs have been touted as inspiration for advanced active materials that may offer promise as soft robotic systems. However, developing engineered, active, filamentous systems that can be programmed to undergo reversible movements has provided challenges. Here, we develop a new class of mesoscale polymer ribbons that can achieve these active, reversible motions. The introduction of a new fabrication method for mesoscale ribbons that preserve their chemical fidelity was a key development, as well as the demonstration of performing chemical functionalization on mesoscale ribbons to imbue them with the ability to entangle or disentangle in response to pH changes. These developments represent significant steps in achieving an engineered materials system that mimics worm blobs, opening opportunities for soft robotics and adaptable materials.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of this project is based on the three specific accomplishments:

  1. The development and demonstration of mesoscale polymer ribbon fabrication that preserve the intrinsic chemistry of the polymer building blocks. The key finding was the identification of processing conditions that enabled the autonomous dewetting of residual film that typically connects neighboring mesoscale ribbons during their printing process. The preservation of their intrinsic chemistry is significant for opening pathways of modifying their chemistry in the post-production stages.

  2. The fabrication of mesoscale polymer ribbons that possess a wide range of mechanical properties at room temperature. The significance of this accomplishment is the ability to create mesoscale polymer ribbons from materials that can be elastic, hence reversible, even through large deformations. The key demonstration in this accomplishment was the production of mesoscale polymer ribbons from polybutadiene as well as block copolymers of polybutadiene and polystyrene. This materials system allowed the elastic moduli for the mesoscale polymer ribbons to range from MPa to GPa.

  3. The demonstration of reversible shape transformations of mesoscale polymer ribbons enabled by chemical functionality. The key demonstration in this accomplishment was subjecting polybutadiene mesoscale polymer ribbons to thiol-ene click conditions with mercaptopropionic acid. The mesoscale ribbons following thiol-ene treatment become responsive to changes in the pH of the surrounding solution; this introduction of charge suggests their role as mesoscale polyelectrolytes (MPEs).  The new MPEs were shown through video microscopy to undergo rapid, large transformations, including entanglement and disentanglement, upon changing the pH of the surrounding liquid environment.

Broader Impacts

The mesoscale polymer ribbons and the manufacturing methods developed for the materials systems introduced in this project offer exciting advances for new technologies, including adaptable composites, smart fabrics, and reconfigurable electronic systems. Additionally, the PIs and the graduate student involved in this project have had extensive broader impacts through their regular participation in education outreach programs. The graduate student funded by this project participated in the ASPIRE outreach program, which hosts each year approximately 30-40 high school students from the Western Massachusetts region on five Saturday mornings during the winter to teach them fundamentals of polymer chemistry, physics, and engineering. The PIs played leading roles in significant outreach programs at the K-12 and undergraduate levels. At the K-12 level, laboratory tours and demonstrations focused on bioinspired soft materials physics and engineering were organized with elementary schools from the Amherst Regional Public School district, which serves a diverse population. At the undergraduate level, one of the PIs is the lead organizer and founder of the ASCENDS REU program, which hosts underrepresented minority undergraduate researchers from undergraduate institutes across the nation. This program has had great success, with former participants continuing the STEM education in graduate programs in the U.S.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2024
Modified by: Alfred J Crosby

Project Outcomes Summar


This collaborative project focused on the development of mesoscale polymer ribbons that can mimic Lubriculus variegatus worms, which form aggregate blobs in nature. These developments represent significant steps in achieving an engineered materials system that mimics worm blobs, opening opportunities for soft robotics and adaptable materials.

This program has had great success, with former participants continuing the STEM education in graduate programs in the U.S.
